awd_titl_txt: Long-Term Human Land, Forest, and Water Management in a Tropical Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this research is to understand the processes which led to the emergence of complex large scale social groups in tropical environments. The researchers wish to understand the land and water management strategies that support such occurrences in regions of potentially low carrying capacity. Archaeology provides a valuable way to gain insight because it has the potential to trace such processes over extend periods of time. A team of researchers from the University of Cincinnati together with an international group of colleagues have identified a site, which through excavation and field research will permit them to achieve this goal. Investigation of the hydraulic, agricultural, and forest management strategies that allowed the persistent occupation  in the face of changing environmental and political economic conditions will provide insights that will broaden understanding of the rise of social complexity, the expansion of political economy specifically and, in general terms, the trajectory of cultural evolution. The research will provide for training of graduate students and the results will be disseminated through institutional websites, popular media, undergraduate and graduate courses, as well as through scientific journals and conference presentations.

The archaeological site of Yaxnohcah located in the Mayan lowlands provides a test case.  It grew into a large urban center early in the Preclassic period, survived a broader regional collaples and continued to be occupied in later prehistoric times. It is hypothesized that the complex topography associated with Yaxnohcah's location between two bajos,(lowland swampy areas) as well as the many embayments created a landscape with a great diversity of drainage and soil types and forest cover that provided early occupants with an ideal location to experiment with a wide array of cultigens and management practices that were adapted over time to changing environmental and cultural circumstances. In particular, the research addresses the development of hydraulic systems at Yaxnohcah, especially as they contributed to agricultural activity, forest clearance and exploitation of the bajos. The acquisition of LiDAR imagery of the site area and environs in 2014 allows selection of a variety of topographic settings, probable ancient agricultural fields, reservoirs/aguadas, and residential areas for excavation and coring, thus providing data on resource management across the spectrum of environmental contexts and social strata present at Yaxnohcah.

por.por_cntn:
Maintaining a sustainable balance between economic and population growth and meeting basic human needs such as water, food, and fuel have posed challenges for all civilizations throughout human history. Ancient Maya Civilization persisted from roughly 1000 BC to 1500 AD. Yet, that long span was punctuated by episodes of significant disruption including abandonment of some major cities. Our investigations were focused on the ancient city of Yaxnohcah, situated in what is today the Calakmul Biosphere Reserve, a conservation area of tropical forest in Campeche, Mexico. Yaxnohcah grew into a major urban complex during the Maya Preclassic period (1000 BC - 250 AD), declined in the Early Classic, then became a major "suburb" of Calakmul, a dominant centers of the Late Classic period (AD 600 -800).  We sought the underlying resource management issues that underlay this dynamic urban history. 

Yaxnohcah lies within the Elevated Interior Region (EIR) of the Yucatan Peninsula, an area with extreme water-related challenges: a seasonal precipitation regime including a 5/6-month dry season, and a karst environment with very few natural perennial water sources. In order to support urban population concentrations within the EIR, the Maya devised systems for capturing and storing rainwater. At Yaxnohcah, this system included some ten major reservoirs as well as hundreds of household tanks adjacent to residential complexes.

The construction of the initial major reservoir, Brisa, took place around 800 BC, coeval with the erection of the first monumental architecture at the site, Complejo Brisa: the elevated and plastered buildings and plaza of Complejo Briza provided part of the rain/runoff catchment that filled the reservoir.  One of the problems identified by the inhabitants of Yaxnohcah was the need to keep reservoir water clean. Reservoirs such as Brisa that received runoff from large catchments faced the issue of runoff of sediment and possible contaminants. In the Late Preclassic, between 350 BC and 150 AD reservoirs proliferated across the expanding urban area: these reservoirs showed an increasing attention to keeping water clean. 

Our investigations also looked at the hundreds of much smaller household-scale reservoirs spread across the urban landscape. These "tanks" are typically located adjacent to residential groups and began as quarries that supplied the limestone for platform and structure construction and were then sealed to collect and retain rainwater. Excavated examples indicate that construction history was coeval with that of the large, civic reservoirs. 

Another aspect of our project was the investigation of ancient landscape change and agriculture. We documented several periods of landscape destabilization that resulted in accelerated soil erosion and sedimentation in parts of the Yaxnohcah area. One of these periods occurred during the heart of the Preclassic occupation when forest clearance and quarrying were widespread. Another occurred in the Late Classic period when the northern half of the site was densely reoccupied. The Maya responded to notable landscape degradation with land reclamation efforts in several areas including footslope terracing, contour terracing and box terracing, 

We used a combination of methods to document the nature of ancient agriculture and forest management at Yaxnohcah. Fossil pollen was collected from reservoir sediments and from buried soils in geoarchaeological trenches.  On-site flotation screening allowed us to recover an abundance of carbonized plant remains from a large variety of contexts. Carbonized plant remains provided information on the types of trees in use at various times and crops that were being grown. Additionally, we collected sediment/soil samples for use in environmental DNA (eDNA) analysis. The eDNA in soil and sediment  can provide a picture of the vegetation that existed on ancient landscapes at different times in the past. These data were compared with the results of our intensive transect surveys of the contemporary forest. We found that the forest composition was highly similar, though affected by periods of Maya forest clearance, and also effected by a period of selective logging that occurred in the latter half of the 20th century.

As we had hypothesized, the Maya of Yaxnohcah did not completely denude the landscape of forest even during the two periods of peak populations (Late Preclassic and Late Classic). Rather, the evidence we obtained suggest that significant areas of managed forest remained across the greater site area. Such forest would have provided the area occupants with firewood, construction timber, bark (used for cloth and paper), nuts, fruits, and medicines. We also found evidence that the Maya of Yaxnohcah grew a wide variety of crops, including maize, beans, squashes, chilis, manioc, and cotton. We found evidence of continued cultivation in some areas into the Early Postclassic after much of the site had been abandoned. 

Our research is being shared in numerous academic publications, some of which are in print, others in press, others in review, and some still in preparation.  It also resulted in the completion of three PhD degrees and one MA  in the US and Mexico.
